title: Johnson & Johnson Tylenol Crisis (1982)
summary: When seven people died after taking cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules, Johnson & Johnson's transparent and swift response — including a nationwide product recall — became the gold standard for crisis communications.
background: In 1982, unknown individuals tampered with Tylenol capsules on store shelves in the Chicago area. The crisis threatened to destroy one of America's most trusted consumer brands.
response: J&J CEO James Burke immediately put consumer safety above all else, issued a nationwide recall of 31 million bottles, cooperated fully with authorities, and developed tamper-resistant packaging — all communicated transparently to the public.
outcome: Tylenol regained 95% of its pre-crisis market share within a year. The response is studied globally as the definitive example of effective crisis PR.
lessons: Take responsibility even without confirmed fault
discussion_questions: Why did consumers trust J&J's response?
How would this crisis be managed differently in the social media age?
